Week 2 Discussion Notes

Table of Contents

  • L'Hôpital's Rule

    • Pitfalls
    • Examples

  • Integrals

L'Hôpital's Rule

Here's an abridged statement of L'Hôpital's rule:

Theorem (L'Hôpital's rule)

Let f(x),g(x)f\p{x}, g\p{x}f(x),g(x) be functions such that

  1. lim⁡x→af(x)=lim⁡x→ag(x)=0\lim_{x\to a} f\p{x} = \lim_{x\to a} g\p{x} = 0limx→a​f(x)=limx→a​g(x)=0 or lim⁡x→af(x)\lim_{x\to a} f\p{x}limx→a​f(x) and lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x\to a} g\p{x}limx→a​g(x) are both infinite.
  2. lim⁡x→af′(x)g′(x)\lim_{x\to a} \frac{f'\p{x}}{g'\p{x}}limx→a​g′(x)f′(x)​ exists or is infinite.

Then

lim⁡x→af(x)g(x)=lim⁡x→af′(x)g′(x).\lim_{x\to a} \frac{f\p{x}}{g\p{x}} = \lim_{x\to a} \frac{f'\p{x}}{g'\p{x}}.x→alim​g(x)f(x)​=x→alim​g′(x)f′(x)​.

It's slightly different from the textbook's definition because I wanted to focus on what I think are the more interesting conditions.

Pitfalls

Don't use the quotient rule!

Example 1.

Calculate lim⁡x→∞xex\displaystyle \lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{x}{e^x}x→∞lim​exx​.
Solution.

As x→∞x \to \inftyx→∞, the numerator and denominator both go to ∞\infty∞ also, so we can apply L'Hôpital's rule. Sometimes, students will write something like this:

lim⁡x→∞xex=lim⁡x→∞ex−xexe2x=0.\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{x}{e^x} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x - xe^x}{e^{2x}} = 0.x→∞lim​exx​=x→∞lim​e2xex−xex​=0.

The problem with this is that instead of taking the derivative of the numerator and denominator separately, this is the derivative of the entire fraction, which is wrong. Instead, you should end up with

lim⁡x→∞xex=lim⁡x→∞1ex=0.\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{x}{e^x} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{1}{e^x} = \boxed{0}.x→∞lim​exx​=x→∞lim​ex1​=0​.

Assumptions matter!

Example 2.

Calculate lim⁡x→0x2cos⁡x\displaystyle \lim_{x\to0} \frac{x^2}{\cos{x}}x→0lim​cosxx2​.
Solution.

The following thing is wrong:

lim⁡x→0x2cos⁡x=lim⁡x→02x−sin⁡x=lim⁡x→0−2sin⁡xx=−2.\lim_{x\to0} \frac{x^2}{\cos{x}} = \lim_{x\to0} \frac{2x}{-\sin{x}} = \lim_{x\to0} -\frac{2}{\frac{\sin{x}}{x}} = -2.x→0lim​cosxx2​=x→0lim​−sinx2x​=x→0lim​−xsinx​2​=−2.

The problem here is that we didn't check condition (i) before applying L'Hôpital's rule. If we go back, you'll see that as x→0x \to 0x→0, the numerator goes to 000 but the denominator goes to 111, so we could've just plugged in to begin with:

lim⁡x→0x2cos⁡x=0.\lim_{x\to0} \frac{x^2}{\cos{x}} = \boxed{0}.x→0lim​cosxx2​=0​.
Example 3.

Calculate lim⁡x→∞x+sin⁡xx\displaystyle \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{x + \sin{x}}{x}x→∞lim​xx+sinx​.
Solution.

This is also wrong:

lim⁡x→∞x+sin⁡xx=lim⁡x→01+cos⁡x1=DNE.\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{x + \sin{x}}{x} = \lim_{x\to0} \frac{1 + \cos{x}}{1} = \dne.x→∞lim​xx+sinx​=x→0lim​11+cosx​=DNE.

This is because condition (ii) failed: the limit of f′(x)g′(x)\frac{f'\p{x}}{g'\p{x}}g′(x)f′(x)​ doesn't exist here, so you can't write the first equals sign. This means we need to try something else:

lim⁡x→∞x+sin⁡xx=lim⁡x→∞(1+sin⁡xx)=1.\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{x + \sin{x}}{x} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \p{1 + \frac{\sin{x}}{x}} = \boxed{1}.x→∞lim​xx+sinx​=x→∞lim​(1+xsinx​)=1​.

Your old techniques are still useful!

Even though L'Hôpital's rule is really useful, this doesn't mean that you can just forget all your old techniques for calculating limits. Example 3 above is one instance of this, and we also have this one:

Example 4.

Calculate lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x\displaystyle \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}}x→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​.
Solution.

The numerator and denominator both go to ∞\infty∞ as x→∞x \to \inftyx→∞, so we can apply L'Hôpital's rule:

lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x=lim⁡x→∞ex+e−xex−e−x.\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x + e^{-x}}{e^x - e^{-x}}.x→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​=x→∞lim​ex−e−xex+e−x​.

Same thing happens with the new limit, so you try it again:

lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x=lim⁡x→∞ex+e−xex−e−x=lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x=⋯ .\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x + e^{-x}}{e^x - e^{-x}} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} = \cdots.x→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​=x→∞lim​ex−e−xex+e−x​=x→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​=⋯.

Hopefully you realize that after two tries that L'Hôpital's isn't going to get you anywhere. This means that you will have to try one of your old techniques to calculate it. For this problem, you'll want to divide everything by the fastest growing function, which is exe^xex in this case:

lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x⋅1ex1ex=lim⁡x→∞1−e−2x1+e−2x=1.\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{e^x}}{\frac{1}{e^x}} = \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{1 - e^{-2x}}{1 + e^{-2x}} = \boxed{1}.x→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​⋅ex1​ex1​​=x→∞lim​1+e−2x1−e−2x​=1​.

Examples

Example 5.

Calculate lim⁡x→0+sin⁡x−x21−cos⁡2x\displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\sin{x} - x^2}{\sqrt{1 - \cos^2{x}}}x→0+lim​1−cos2x​sinx−x2​.
Solution.

Before using L'Hôpital's, you should always take a minute to see if you can simplify anything. In this problem, if you don't do that, you end up with a horrible derivative in the denominator. But if you do simplify, you will just get sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx in the bottom—much nicer! If you use L'Hôpital's after this, you just get

lim⁡x→0+sin⁡x−x21−cos⁡2x=lim⁡x→0+sin⁡x−x2sin⁡x=lim⁡x→0+cos⁡x−2xcos⁡x=1.\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\sin{x} - x^2}{\sqrt{1 - \cos^2{x}}} = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\sin{x} - x^2}{\sin{x}} = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\cos{x} - 2x}{\cos{x}} = \boxed{1}.x→0+lim​1−cos2x​sinx−x2​=x→0+lim​sinxsinx−x2​=x→0+lim​cosxcosx−2x​=1​.
Example 6.

Calculate lim⁡x→0+x2x\displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0^+} x^{2\sqrt{x}}x→0+lim​x2x​.
Solution.

Here, we're going to want to use logarithms to bring the exponent down, but we need to make sure we undo it so that we don't change the function:

lim⁡x→0+x2x=lim⁡x→0+eln⁡x2x=elim⁡x→0+2xln⁡x.\lim_{x \to 0^+} x^{2\sqrt{x}} = \lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{\ln{x^{2\sqrt{x}}}} = e^{\lim_{x \to 0^+} 2\sqrt{x}\ln{x}}.x→0+lim​x2x​=x→0+lim​elnx2x​=elimx→0+​2x​lnx.

The second equality comes from continuity of exe^xex. It's somewhat technical (you need to do some ε\epsilonε-δ\deltaδ stuff to prove it), so I'll just gloss over the details since they won't be important for our class.

To finish the problem, we just need to calculate lim⁡x→0+2xln⁡x\lim_{x \to 0^+} 2\sqrt{x}\ln{x}limx→0+​2x​lnx. If we want to use L'Hôpital's rule, we need a fraction, but thankfully, we can always turn a product into a quotient:

2xln⁡x=2ln⁡x1x.2\sqrt{x}\ln{x} = \frac{2\ln{x}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}}.2x​lnx=x​1​2lnx​.

I could've moved ln⁡x\ln{x}lnx to the denominator instead, but then we'd have to calculate the derivative of 1ln⁡x\frac{1}{\ln{x}}lnx1​ which will get messy, so it'll be easier to keep ln⁡x\ln{x}lnx in the numerator. Then

lim⁡x→0+2xln⁡x=lim⁡x→0+2ln⁡x1x=lim⁡x→0+2ln⁡xx−1/2=lim⁡x→0+2x−12x−3/2=lim⁡x→0+−4x⋅x3/2=lim⁡x→0+−4x1/2=0.\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0^+} 2\sqrt{x} \ln{x} &= \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{2\ln{x}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{2\ln{x}}{x^{-1/2}} \\ &= \lim_{x\to0^+} \frac{\frac{2}{x}}{-\frac{1}{2}x^{-3/2}} \\ &= \lim_{x\to0^+} -\frac{4}{x} \cdot x^{3/2} \\ &= \lim_{x\to0^+} -4x^{1/2} \\ &= 0. \end{aligned}x→0+lim​2x​lnx​=x→0+lim​x​1​2lnx​=x→0+lim​x−1/22lnx​=x→0+lim​−21​x−3/2x2​​=x→0+lim​−x4​⋅x3/2=x→0+lim​−4x1/2=0.​

Finally, we need to evaluate the original limit:

lim⁡x→0+x2x=elim⁡x→0+2xln⁡x=e0=1.\lim_{x \to 0^+} x^{2\sqrt{x}} = e^{\lim_{x \to 0^+} 2\sqrt{x}\ln{x}} = e^0 = \boxed{1}.x→0+lim​x2x​=elimx→0+​2x​lnx=e0=1​.
Example 7.

Calculate lim⁡x→∞∣x+1x−2∣x2−4\displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} \abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}^{\sqrt{x^2 - 4}}x→∞lim​∣∣​x−2x+1​∣∣​x2−4​.
Solution.

Like in the previous example, we're going to take a logarithm to bring the exponent down:

lim⁡x→∞∣x+1x−2∣x2−4=elim⁡x→∞x2−4ln⁡∣x+1x−2∣.\lim_{x \to \infty} \abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}^{\sqrt{x^2 - 4}} = e^{\lim_{x \to \infty} \sqrt{x^2 - 4}\ln\abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}}.x→∞lim​∣∣​x−2x+1​∣∣​x2−4​=elimx→∞​x2−4​ln∣x−2x+1​∣.

Then to calculate the limit in the exponent,

lim⁡x→∞x2−4ln⁡∣x+1x−2∣=lim⁡x→∞ln⁡∣x+1x−2∣1x2−4=lim⁡x→∞ln⁡∣x+1∣−ln⁡∣x−2∣(x2−4)−1/2=lim⁡x→∞1x+1−1x−2−x(x2−4)−3/2=lim⁡x→∞x−2(x+1)(x−2)−x+1(x+1)(x−2)−x⋅(x2−4)3/2=lim⁡x→∞−3(x2−4)3/2−x(x+1)(x−2)=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4)3/2x(x+1)(x−2)\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \infty} \sqrt{x^2 - 4}\ln\abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}} &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\ln\abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 - 4}}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\ln\abs{x + 1} - \ln\abs{x - 2}}{\p{x^2 - 4}^{-1/2}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{x+1} - \frac{1}{x-2}}{-x\p{x^2 - 4}^{-3/2}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\frac{x-2}{\p{x+1}\p{x-2}} - \frac{x+1}{\p{x+1}\p{x-2}}}{-x} \cdot \p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{-3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}}{-x\p{x+1}\p{x-2}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}}{x\p{x+1}\p{x-2}} \end{aligned}x→∞lim​x2−4​ln∣∣​x−2x+1​∣∣​​=x→∞lim​x2−4​1​ln∣∣​x−2x+1​∣∣​​=x→∞lim​(x2−4)−1/2ln∣x+1∣−ln∣x−2∣​=x→∞lim​−x(x2−4)−3/2x+11​−x−21​​=x→∞lim​−x(x+1)(x−2)x−2​−(x+1)(x−2)x+1​​⋅(x2−4)3/2=x→∞lim​−x(x+1)(x−2)−3(x2−4)3/2​=x→∞lim​x(x+1)(x−2)3(x2−4)3/2​​

When xxx is large, (x2−4)3/2\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}(x2−4)3/2 is roughly (x2)3/2=x3\p{x^2}^{3/2} = x^3(x2)3/2=x3, and the denominator is also roughly x3x^3x3. So, we will multiply and divide by 1x3\frac{1}{x^3}x31​. Notice that x3=(x2)3/2x^3 = \p{x^2}^{3/2}x3=(x2)3/2, which gives

=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4)3/2x(x+1)(x+2)⋅1x31x3=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4)3/2(1x2)3/2x(x+1)(x−2)x3=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4x2)3/2xxx+1xx−2x=lim⁡x→∞3(1−4x2)3/2(1+1x)(1−2x)=3.\begin{aligned} &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}}{x\p{x+1}\p{x+2}} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{x^3}}{\frac{1}{x^3}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2} \p{\frac{1}{x^2}}^{3/2}}{\frac{x\p{x+1}\p{x-2}}{x^3}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{\frac{x^2 - 4}{x^2}}^{3/2}}{\frac{x}{x} \frac{x+1}{x} \frac{x-2}{x}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{1 - \frac{4}{x^2}}^{3/2}}{\p{1 + \frac{1}{x}}\p{1 - \frac{2}{x}}} \\ &= 3. \end{aligned}​=x→∞lim​x(x+1)(x+2)3(x2−4)3/2​⋅x31​x31​​=x→∞lim​x3x(x+1)(x−2)​3(x2−4)3/2(x21​)3/2​=x→∞lim​xx​xx+1​xx−2​3(x2x2−4​)3/2​=x→∞lim​(1+x1​)(1−x2​)3(1−x24​)3/2​=3.​

Finally, we just need to go back to the original limit:

lim⁡x→∞∣x+1x−2∣x2−4=elim⁡x→∞x2−4ln⁡∣x+1x−2∣=e3.\lim_{x \to \infty} \abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}^{\sqrt{x^2 - 4}} = e^{\lim_{x \to \infty} \sqrt{x^2 - 4}\ln\abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}} = \boxed{e^3}.x→∞lim​∣∣​x−2x+1​∣∣​x2−4​=elimx→∞​x2−4​ln∣x−2x+1​∣=e3​.

Integrals

Example 8.

Calculate ∫eex+x dx\displaystyle \int e^{e^x+x} \,\diff{x}∫eex+xdx.
Solution.

Usually, it's a good idea to get rid of addition in the exponent since multiplication is easier to work with:

∫eex+x dx=∫eexex dx.\int e^{e^x+x} \,\diff{x} = \int e^{e^x} e^x \,\diff{x}.∫eex+xdx=∫eexexdx.

One choice of uuu is u=exu = e^xu=ex, which means du=ex dx\diff{u} = e^x \,\diff{x}du=exdx. Then

∫eexex dx=∫eu du=eu+C=eex+C.\int e^{e^x} e^x \,\diff{x} = \int e^u \,\diff{u} = e^u + C = \boxed{e^{e^x} + C}.∫eexexdx=∫eudu=eu+C=eex+C​.
Example 9.

Calculate ∫e2x−1e2x+1 dx\displaystyle \int \frac{e^{2x} - 1}{e^{2x} + 1} \,\diff{x}∫e2x+1e2x−1​dx.
Solution.

This one is basically a trick. You want to turn everything into terms of exe^xex, so you can do

∫e2x−1e2x+1⋅1ex1ex dx=∫ex−e−xex+e−x dx.\int \frac{e^{2x} - 1}{e^{2x} + 1} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{e^x}}{\frac{1}{e^x}} \,\diff{x} = \int \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} \,\diff{x}.∫e2x+1e2x−1​⋅ex1​ex1​​dx=∫ex+e−xex−e−x​dx.

From here, u=ex+e−xu = e^x + e^{-x}u=ex+e−x works since du=(ex−e−x) dx\diff{u} = \p{e^x - e^{-x}} \,\diff{x}du=(ex−e−x)dx, which is exactly the numerator, so

∫ex−e−xex+e−x dx=∫duu=ln⁡∣u∣+C=ln⁡∣ex−e−x∣+C.\int \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} \,\diff{x} = \int \frac{\diff{u}}{u} = \ln{\abs{u}} + C = \boxed{\ln{\abs{e^x - e^{-x}}} + C}.∫ex+e−xex−e−x​dx=∫udu​=ln∣u∣+C=ln∣∣​ex−e−x∣∣​+C​.
Exercise 1.

To see if you understand the trick, try calculating these:

  1. ∫e4x−1e4x+1 dx\displaystyle \int \frac{e^{4x} - 1}{e^{4x} + 1} \,\diff{x}∫e4x+1e4x−1​dx
  2. ∫e3x−1e3x+1 dx\displaystyle \int \frac{e^{3x} - 1}{e^{3x} + 1} \,\diff{x}∫e3x+1e3x−1​dx
Example 10.

Calculate ∫sin⁡2x dx\displaystyle \int \sin^2{x} \,\diff{x}∫sin2xdx.
Solution.

This is basically a problem testing to see if you remember the double-angle identities:

∫sin⁡2x dx=∫1−cos⁡2x2 dx=x2−sin⁡2x4+C.\int \sin^2{x} \,\diff{x} = \int \frac{1 - \cos{2x}}{2} \,\diff{x} = \boxed{\frac{x}{2} - \frac{\sin{2x}}{4} + C}.∫sin2xdx=∫21−cos2x​dx=2x​−4sin2x​+C​.
